name: Infrastructure and Network Services
description: A comprehensive feature encompassing software and tools required for building, managing, and maintaining modern IT infrastructure and networking services. This includes server and client software for backups, identity management, directory services, cloud infrastructure, high availability, storage solutions, resilient networking, advanced connectivity, load balancing, and support for both legacy and modern network protocols.

name: Desktop Environment and Software Development Toolkit
description: This parent feature encompasses tools, libraries, and packages necessary for setting up and developing applications across various Linux desktop environments and containerized solutions. It provides resources for both end-users and developers to work with modern graphical desktop environments like GNOME, KDE, and Xfce, as well as containerization technology through Docker and Kubernetes. It includes support for development in key frameworks and libraries such as GTK+, KDE Frameworks (Qt5 and Qt6), and multimedia, office, and educational applications. Additionally, it offers initial setup tools for configuring desktop environments and packages for effective personal information management and software development.

name: System Utilities and Development Tools
description: This parent feature encompasses a comprehensive collection of tools and utilities designed for system administration, hardware configuration, debugging, performance analysis, graphical and console-based system management, and software development. It also includes specialized tools for scientific, engineering, security, and networking purposes, as well as support for advanced systems and specific hardware. These utilities provide functionality for both graphical and command-line interfaces, catering to a wide range of use cases including enterprise-level configurations, high-performance computing, and mainframe access.

name: Cross-Language and Legacy Compatibility Framework
description: A comprehensive framework providing support for various programming languages, development environments, and legacy compatibility. This framework enables seamless development, migration, and execution of applications using diverse programming languages and compatibility layers. It includes support for legacy UNIX environments, older font packages, and interoperability with Windows systems. Developers can access a wide range of tools and libraries to work with popular languages like Java, Python, Perl, Ruby, Haskell, OCaml, and PHP, as well as specialized support for cross-compilation to Windows targets and Java platforms for Linux. Additionally, the framework supports compatibility libraries for applications dependent on previous Linux versions and offers enhanced web development capabilities, including robust frameworks like Ruby on Rails, Python, and Perl for web application support. The inclusion of both modern tools and legacy compatibility features ensures a versatile and interoperable Linux environment.

name: Desktop Environment and Window Management
description: This parent feature encompasses a wide range of graphical user interface environments, window management systems, and supportive tools for a seamless desktop experience. It includes traditional desktop environments, modern desktop UX technologies, lightweight and tiling window managers, application ecosystems tailored for specific desktops, and accessibility features. In addition, it covers compatibility and development tools for X Window System, Wayland compositors, and other essential graphical technologies. The aim is to provide users the flexibility to choose a desktop or window management setup that meets their needs, from feature-rich environments to minimalistic configurations.
children: Extra games for the GNOME Desktop

name: Critical Path Feature Set
description: The Critical Path Feature Set is a comprehensive parent feature that encompasses a series of sub-features representing key functionalities and package groups required for the core operations and performance of various Linux environments and workflows. These features define sets of critical components that ensure the successful operation and stability of applications, desktop environments, system builds, deliverable creation, installation processes, and server editions. Each sub-feature caters to a specific use case or environment, ensuring that the critical needs of diverse Linux deployments are met.

name: Desktop Environment and Productivity Suite
description: An aggregated feature encompassing desktop environments, office suites, and productivity tools for various Linux desktop ecosystems. This parent feature includes support for multiple desktop environments like Deepin, LXDE, and Xfce, as well as diverse sets of applications and toolkits aimed at enhancing user productivity. These include media packages, office software, toolkits like Keentune, and comprehensive features that support critical paths and interoperability across different Linux environments.

name: Cloud and Virtualization Tools
description: A comprehensive feature encompassing tools, packages, and utilities for managing cloud environments, virtualized systems, and containerized workloads. This parent feature integrates support for cloud-specific bootloaders, system and server management in virtualized environments, graphical and headless virtualization setups, platform-specific drivers and utilities for Hyper-V, KVM, VMware, and other hypervisors. It includes management tools for Linux containers, remote desktop clients, and interfaces for remote system management. Additionally, this feature provides agent software for optimized operation under hypervisors, utilities for managing and creating virtual images, and tools to support virtualization platforms, including Open vSwitch and libvirt. Designed for both cloud-native and virtualized systems, this feature delivers flexible and robust infrastructure for modern IT environments.

name: Networked Services and Application Hosting
description: This parent feature encompasses a wide range of services and tools that enable a Linux system to host web-based applications, provide networked services, facilitate printing capabilities, and manage communication protocols. It includes support for application and web servers, email and news servers, file transfer management, 3D printing software, internet applications, and text-based or graphical internet usage. These tools collectively allow the system to function as a versatile platform for hosting, printing, and various client-server integrations.

name: Unified Linux Product Feature Management
description: This parent feature encapsulates the functionality and requirements necessary to manage package support, conflicts, and OSTree compliance across various Linux product variants, including Atomic Host, Client, ComputeNode, Server, and Workstation. It provides a cohesive framework to ensure mandatory package inclusion and conflict resolution for different installation contexts and repositories, enabling smoother workflows and robust system deployment.

name: Content Creation, Development, and Educational Tools Suite
description: A comprehensive suite of tools and environments designed for content creation, software development, technical writing, and educational purposes. This includes tools for document authoring, publishing, coding, scientific computation, and collaborative learning. It caters to users ranging from developers and educators to students and content creators, providing specialized utilities for every need.

name: Database and Certificate Management Systems
description: This parent feature encompasses tools, systems, and components related to database management and certificate authority solutions. It includes support for various relational database management systems (RDBMS), database server and client software, and enterprise-class open source certificate systems. These sub-features provide diverse database solutions for cloud platforms, open source environments, and enterprise use cases, along with robust tools for managing digital certificates and securing communications.

name: Lightweight Desktop Ecosystem and Functional Applications
description: A comprehensive suite of lightweight desktop environments, applications, and multimedia support designed for resource-efficient computing. This feature covers desktop environments such as LXDE, LXQt, and Xfce, along with their respective applications, plugins, translations, and functionality. It also includes multimedia frameworks, critical path functionalities, and other utilities to enhance usability while maintaining performance on low-specification machines.
children: Extra plugins for the Xfce panel

name: Linux Development and Production Environment
description: A comprehensive parent feature encompassing tools, libraries, environments, and utilities to support various facets of Linux-based software development, production, and design. It includes core system components, development tools for multiple programming languages, design suites, audio production tools, and specialized toolsets for robotics, font design, and packaging. This parent feature is aimed at providing a unified and flexible environment for developers, designers, and production specialists working on open-source and Linux-based applications.
